title: Synthetic Recap
body:
DALLAS – In an era defined by offensive firepower, the Phoenix Suns authored a defensive masterpiece, grounded in the singular, historic brilliance of Jason Kidd.

The final score, a decisive 89-75 victory over the Dallas Mavericks, tells only half the story. The other half is etched entirely in Kidd’s transcendent stat line, a triple-double so rare it echoed through the rafters of Reunion Arena. The Suns’ floor general didn’t just command the game; he dominated it from every conceivable angle, amassing a monstrous **22 points, 25 rebounds, and 12 assists.**

The 25 rebounds were not a misprint. They were a declaration. Kidd, a guard, outmuscled and outmaneuvered every big man on the floor, relentlessly controlling the glass and extinguishing any chance of a Dallas second-chance opportunity. His 12 assists were the engine of the Suns’ offense, slicing through the Mavericks’ defense with precision passes.

While Michael Finley provided a valiant 22-point effort for Dallas, his performance was ultimately a solo act drowned out by Kidd’s symphony. The Mavericks, as a team, were simply overwhelmed by one man’s will.

This was not merely a win; it was an announcement. Jason Kedd’s line of 22 points, 25 rebounds, and 12 assists stands as one of the most unique and dominant triple-doubles in league history, a testament to a guard playing with the heart of a center and the vision of a chess master. On this night, the Suns didn’t just have the best player on the court; they had a force of nature.
